I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) has ambitious 
economic  growth  and  social  targets  in  its  forthcoming  Seventh  Five-Year  National  Socio-
Economic Development Plan (NSEDP7), 2011–2015. However, the statistical system to monitor 
progress and evaluate results is very weak. Monitoring of progress toward the Millennium 
Development Goals by 2015 is also hampered by the questionable quality of data, given the 
state of the statistical system. Against this background, the government requested capacity 
development technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist with 
human resources capacity strengthening to implement the Strategy for the Development of the 
National Statistical System, 2010−2020. The Lao Resident Mission fielded a fact-finding mission, 
which  reached  agreement  with  the  government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the 
proposed TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Recent developments. In line with ADB’s new approach to Statistical Capacity Building2 
in developing member countries with very weak statistical capacity, ADB provided technical 
support for a diagnostic study of the Lao PDR statistical system in 2008.3 This was followed by 
two  major  developments  in  the  Lao  PDR’s  national  statistical  system:  (i)  the  government 
prepared and adopted the Strategy for the Development of the National Statistical System in 
May  2010,  and  (ii) the  National  Assembly  passed  the  Statistics  Law  in  June  2010.  The 
strategies provide a long-term framework for development of official statistics needed to support 
the policy and planning process, and for monitoring socioeconomic development. This brings 
the Lao PDR among the nations that have a long-term national strategy, as agreed in the 
Marrakech Action Plan for Statistics in 2004.4 The passing of the Statistics Law provides the 
legal foundation for statistical activities across the national statistical system in a harmonized 
manner, with the Department of Statistics (DOS) playing the central coordinating role. These 
policy actions reflect the government’s increasing commitment to and support for the national 
statistical system.  
 
3.  Statistical system and the new statistics law. The statistical system of the Lao PDR is 
highly decentralized—horizontally across different ministries and vertically across provinces, 
districts, and villages, creating management challenges. The DOS undertakes major statistical 
operations such as the population census, and household and establishment surveys; and 
produces national accounts statistics, price statistics, and other statistics needed for Millennium 
Development Goal monitoring. The line ministries collect data in their own areas of operation. 
The Statistics Law identifies the roles and responsibilities of different agencies and makes the 
DOS responsible for central management and coordination. The DOS is also the focal point for 
providing technical guidance to all parties on data collection and the establishment of uniform 
standards. Under the Strategy for the Development of the National Statistical System, the DOS 
will have statistics divisions, units, and teams at provincial and district levels; and will have staff

at  village  level.  At  the  same  time,  statistics work  in  ministries  and  other  central  agencies 
(provinces and sectors) will be strengthened. In 2005, about 350 staff were working in statistics, 
200 of whom were in district offices. The strategies aim to increase staff strength to 1,400 by 
2020 (this includes statistics staff in various divisions and units at provincial level and in the 
ministries).  
  
4.  Challenges of developing staff capacity and skills. The strategy has seven goals and 
12 main work programs (summarized in Supplementary Appendix A).5 One of the seven goals is 
to build and enhance the knowledge of staff and statisticians in the national statistical system. 
The corresponding work program to achieve this is to upgrade the knowledge, competencies, 
and  skills  of  statisticians  to  enable  them  to  become  experts  with  experience  and  skills 
comparable to international standards. This work program requires the establishment of training 
teams to implement training-related work plans at every level—providing training in statistical 
techniques and methodologies; formulating human resource development plans; training in 
organizational management for managers; and training in different aspects of data processing 
and upgrading of educational qualifications of staff by increasing the number of diploma holders, 
graduates, and postgraduates over the next 10 years.  
 
5.  Educating, guiding, and upgrading the knowledge and skills of staff working in the area 
of official statistics is one of the responsibilities of the DOS. However, its capacity to carry out 
these tasks is weak and training facilities at the DOS are very limited. Training opportunities 
offered by the DOS should include introductory courses on the Lao PDR statistical system; a set 
of courses to build basic understanding of statistical methods; basic courses on data collection, 
compilation,  and  presentation;  and  other  basic  and  intermediate  subject  matter  courses. 
Specialized training needs in official statistics—such as national accounts, design of household 
and establishment based sample surveys, and other technical areas of training and education 
for raising qualifications in statistics to diploma and degree level—will have to be undertaken 
overseas in the short to medium term until capacity and opportunities become available in-
country. Development of in-house training capacity is therefore necessary. Training curricula 
should be drafted with the help of outside consultants and the DOS should use this to impart 
training to its own staff as well as staff of central ministries, provinces, and districts. Equally, 
statistics  teaching  and  research  programs  should  begin  to  be  established  at  Lao  PDR 
universities.  
 
6.  External assistance for support of statistics. The Swedish International Development 
Cooperation Agency (Sida) supported the Lao Expenditure and Consumption Survey I–IV, the 
1995 and 2005 population censuses, the 1998 Agriculture Census, the 2006 Economic Census, 
and others. The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) supported the Multiple Indicator 
Cluster Surveys in 1996, 2000, and 2006. The World Bank is supporting the DOS in the 
preparation of a sectoral master plan, the strengthening of the national accounts, undertaking 
poverty analysis using the results of the 2007–2008 Lao Expenditure and Consumption Survey, 
and provision of basic training at provincial and district levels. Other donors have provided 
financial support for the DOS to carry out smaller surveys. Lessons from previous donor support 
are that (i) the legal framework to ensure sustainable capacity development was not in place, 
and (ii) donor support was primarily focused on obtaining survey results. With the end of Sida’s 
assistance in June 2009,6 the government has requested support from donors, including the 
World Bank, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the European Commission, 
the Association of Southeast Asian Nations member countries, and various specialized United

Nations  agencies.  UNDP  has  agreed  to  coordinate  donor  support,  aiming  for  a  more 
harmonized approach, starting in 2011. 
 
7.  Given the major challenges ahead for the new organization, the low level of managerial 
and technical skills, and the difficulty of attracting qualified staff, a long-term phased approach is 
required for building the statistical capacity. The DOS has requested ADB to provide support for 
(i) ensuring a greater awareness of statistical units of their functions under the new Statistics 
Law, (ii) developing the in-house training capacity of the DOS to support the training needs of 
the statistical system envisaged under the Statistics Law and the Strategy for the Development 
of  the  National  Statistical  System,  and  (iii) strengthening  capacity  in  data  processing  and 
analysis of survey data through hands-on-training in data analysis. ADB will initiate and provide 
this support for developing capacity, while the UNDP-led coordination mechanism among the 
development partners in the Lao PDR is being developed. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA impact is an improved monitoring and evaluation of the implementation progress 
of the NSEDP7 in selected sectors through the collection and compilation of timely, reliable, and 
quality statistics. 
 
9.  The  outcome  is  improved  capacity  of  staff  of  the  DOS  and  statistics  units  in  key 
ministries  and  provinces,  as  measured  by  the  adoption  of  sound  statistical  standards  and 
methodologies, and implementation of statistical coordination mechanisms. The outputs are 
(i) statistics units have greater awareness of their functions under the new Statistics Law, (ii) a 
statistics training program is implemented, and (iii) capability to process selected surveys is 
strengthened.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The key activities by output are discussed below. 
 
11.  Output 1: Statistics units have greater awareness of their functions under the new 
Statistics Law. The Statistics Law defines the organizational structure of the national statistical 
system; and the roles and responsibilities, mandates, and authority of the different components 
of the system at various levels. The law thus provides the basis for conduct of statistical 
activities  across  the  national  statistical  system  in  a  harmonized  manner.  The  DOS  will 
disseminate the Statistics Law and its implementing decrees among key stakeholders in central 
ministries and in the provinces. This will enable the DOS to promote and improve awareness 
and understanding of the provisions of the Statistics Law and strengthen coordination among 
data producers. There will be three workshops in central ministries and four workshops in 
provinces, which will target 150–200 participants. Legal documents will also be published for 
distribution to public.  
 
12.  Output 2: Statistics training program is implemented. The objective is to improve the 
skills of statistics personnel at the DOS and relevant ministries (ministries of education, health,

Capital,  Savannakhet,  Champasack,  and  Luangprabang).  This  will  include  (i) developing  a 
training program relevant to the skills needed to implement the Strategy for the Development of 
the  National  Statistical  Systems  and  the  Statistics  Law;  (ii) developing  in-country  training

4 
 
capacity through (a) developing training courses and training materials, and (b) training 10 
trainers and establishing training teams to implement training-related work plans from central to 
local levels; and (iii) providing training on statistical techniques and methodologies in different 
aspects  of  data  collection,  specifically  on  sampling  design  for  conduct  of  household  and 
establishment-based surveys, estimation techniques, data analysis and survey management, 
and  other  technical  areas  of  official  statistics;  report  writing,  data  presentation,  and 
dissemination. 
 
13.  Output 3: Capability to process selected surveys is strengthened. To meet the data 
gaps in the compilation of national accounts and poverty estimation and analysis, this will 
provide support to the annual household and establishment surveys. Activities under this output 
include  the  development  of  the  design  of  survey  processing  and  hands-on  training  and 
mentoring of statistics staff as well as test staff knowledge gained from survey-related training 
under output 2. This will reduce DOS dependency on external consultants in conducting the 
analysis and reporting of survey results. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $800,000  of  which  ADB  will  finance  $690,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV and 
TASF-other  sources).  The  government  will  finance  the  balance  amounting  to  $110,000 
equivalent, in-kind, to cover the cost of counterpart personnel, office space, resource center 
space, equipment and facilities for counterpart staff, administrative and logistic support, and 
other related services. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The DOS, under the Ministry of Planning and Investment, will be the executing agency. 
A steering committee, including members from relevant line ministries (including for agriculture, 
health, education, industry and commerce, and public works and transport) will be established 
under  the  chair  of  the  director  general  of  the  DOS  to  provide  guidance  and  oversee 
implementation of the TA. The project will be implemented in close coordination with various 
departments of line ministries and provincial offices, and key donors. The DOS will provide 
office space, furniture, and support services for the consultants; and the TA will provide office 
computers and supplies.  
 
16.  Three international experts in the areas of  institutional and human resources strategy 
development, statistics training and survey data processing (a total of 17 person-months) and 
one national statistics expert (18 person-months) will be recruited through a consulting firm 
through quality- and cost-based selection in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Equipment procured under this TA will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The assets will be handed over to the DOS upon 
completion of the project. A vehicle will be leased for the use of the consultants.  
  
17.  Dissemination workshops and seminars will be held in Vientiane and provincial capitals. 
Eight persons will receive overseas’ training in the region, possibly Viet Nam or India. Other 
workshops will be held in Vientiane and provincial capitals. The TA will be implemented over 
30 months from January 2011 to June 2013, following the signing of the TA agreement between

5 
 
the government and ADB. Consultant deliverables are included in the terms of reference in 
Appendix 3. The TA will be managed by the Lao Resident Mission.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $690,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for Capacity Strengthening of the 
National Statistical System, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.   Institutional  and  human  resources  strategy  consultant  (2  person-months).  The 
institutional and human resources strategy consultant will have extensive experience of working 
in  national  statistical  systems,  preferably  in  developing  countries,  and  have  a  good 
understanding  of  the  institutional  and  legal  arrangements  (Statistics  Law,  2010)  for  the 
coordinated development of national statistical systems. The consultant will have extensive 
experience  and  technical  background  of  reviewing  and  designing  the  human  resources 
strategies and training needs of national statistical systems, particularly with weak capacity. 
Working closely with the staff of the Department of Statistics (DOS), the consultant will  
 
(i)  assist the DOS in the organization of workshops and seminars at central and 
provincial levels for dissemination of the new Statistics Law and related decrees 
to the producers of official statistics and other stakeholders as laid down in the 
Statistics Law; 
(ii)  act as a key resource person in workshops and seminars; prepare workshop 
materials; promote, advocate, and create awareness about the provisions, rights, 
and duties of producers and users of official statistics under the new Statistics 
Law and its decrees; 
(iii)  undertake  a  training  needs  assessment  to  match  the  skills  needed  for 
statisticians of the DOS and other data producing ministries and agencies that 
will facilitate implementation of the Strategies for the Development of the National 
Statistical System; 
(iv)  design  training  programs  for  statisticians  in  the  DOS  and  other  government 
agencies to upgrade their statistical skills and educational qualifications to equip 
them to collect, compile, analyze, and disseminate data with high quality and 
professionalism; 
(v)  review the existing internal training facilities in the DOS and suggest how they 
could be improved and what statistics training programs should be conducted in 
collaboration with national academic institutions in the short and medium term;  
(vi)  suggest  an  appropriate  mix  of  in-house  and  in-country  training  and  external 
training  programs,  identify  in-country  institutions  and  external  institutions  or 
national statistics offices of neighboring countries that could serve as trainers, 
and identify the funding needs for training and the sources of funding (whether 
government budget or donor funding); and  
(vii)  suggest the infrastructure and/or equipment needs of the DOS for conducting 
training programs, if any. 
 
2.   Statistics training implementation consultant (12 person-months). The consultant will 
have extensive experience in working with national statistics offices, preferably in statistics 
capacity building in developing countries in the region; and will have experience in designing, 
developing, and implementing training programs for government statisticians. The consultant 
will have experience of working in two or more key areas of official statistics, such as national 
accounts, sample surveys, prices, management of statistical offices, and other key functional 
areas of a national statistics office with statistical standards set by the United Nations and its 
agencies. The consultant will  
 
(i)  act as team leader for the technical assistance;

(ii)  develop the training programs that will be imparted by the DOS through its 
training unit (in collaboration with other in-country experts and training and/or 
research  institutions)  to  meet  the  basic  and  intermediate  training  needs  of 
statisticians in the national statistics system; 
(iii)  determine the training duration for the training programs, considering the needs 
of the target groups; 
(iv)  develop the training curriculum for the training programs and prepare training and 
lecture materials that will include lectures, case studies, hands-on exercises, 
project work, discussions, and other related materials for the topics covered in 
the training program, and take into account existing training materials, if any, 
such as training materials developed for training of officials in Viet Nam or other 
existing  training  materials  that  might  be  available  which  should  be  made 
available to the consultant by the DOS; 
(v)  conduct a series of train-the-trainer modules using the materials developed; 
(vi)  assist the DOS in implementing a number of training programs at the national 
and provincial levels for statistics staff; 
(vii)  ensure the training programs and curriculum includes collection and analysis of 
data disaggregated by sex, age, location, ethnicity, and other features; 
(viii)  create a pool of trainers in the DOS, possibly including a few drawn from the 
major ministries, who can carry forward and implement some of the routine 
training activities using the training materials developed; and 
(ix)  perform any other technical and administrative task assigned in relation to the 
terms of reference. 
 
3.  Survey data processing consultant (3 person-months). The consultant will have at 
least  a  bachelor’s  or  master’s  degree  or  equivalent  in  information  technology,  statistics, 
demography, or any other related technical field with special expertise in data processing and 
management.  The  consultant  will  have  extensive  knowledge  of  CSPro,  SPSS,  or  STATA 
software; and familiarity with IHSN Microdata Management Toolkit is an asset. The consultant 
will have extensive experience in computing and designing computerized processing of data 
collected from large-scale sample surveys of households and enterprises. The consultant will 
work closely with the sampling survey consultants and DOS staff, and will transfer knowledge to 
DOS staff to strengthen their capacity in survey data processing. In particular the consultant will 
 
(i)  develop  the  system  design  for  processing  data  collected  in  household  and 
establishment surveys; 
(ii)  design data entry programs for the survey questionnaire; 
(iii)  assist the DOS in completing the data entry by supervising the data entry of the 
data collected in the survey questionnaire using the designed system; 
(iv)  provide adequate training to data entry staff and the supervisors of the data 
processing unit; 
(v)  ensure  the  survey  questionnaire,  data  entry,  system  design,  and  other  data 
processing and programming will allow regression of data based on sex, age, 
location, ethnicity, and other features; 
(vi)  develop  computerized  validation  programs  for  checking  the  validity  and 
consistency of data; 
(vii)  work with the sample survey expert for data analysis, and produce tables in

B.  National Consultant 
 
4.  Statistics consultant (18 months). The national statistics consultant will work under the 
overall  guidance  of  the  international  consultants.  The  national  consultant  will  brief  the 
international consultant on various aspects of the national statistical system of the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic and recent developments, and will provide all necessary research and 
technical support. The consultant will have a very good command of (written and spoken) 
English language and the ability to translate documents from English to Laotian and vice versa. 
The consultant will also act as the interpreter for the international consultant in meetings with 
DOS officials and officials from the central ministries, and in the provinces and districts. In 
particular, the national consultant will 
 
(i)  assist the international consultant in conducting the workshops and seminars for    
dissemination of the Statistics Law and decrees, and in preparing the materials 
and undertaking high quality translation of the documents as necessary for the 
seminar; 
(ii)  assist the training implementation consultant in preparing the training materials 
and undertaking high quality translation from English to Laotian language; 
(iii)  assist the training implementation consultant in conducting the training programs 
at the central, provincial and district levels; and 
(iv)  undertake any other task as required to facilitate effective implementation of the 
technical assistance.
